examples.title: Example 1: Declining puella (Complete Paradigm)
examples.description: Here's the complete declension of puella (girl) with explanations of each form's function.

forms.translation: The life of the girl is good. / The girl's life is good.
I give water to the girl.
The life of the girls is good. / The girls' life is good.
I give water to the girls.

paradigm.note: Notice that puellae appears three times (gen. sg., dat. sg., nom. pl.) and puellīs appears twice (dat. pl., abl. pl.). Context determines which case is meant.

examples.title: Example 3: Identifying Cases in Context
examples.description: Practice identifying which case a noun is in based on the sentence context.

analysis.reason: Subject of the sentence (who is seeing)

sentences.translation: The life of the girl is good. / The girl's life is good.

analysis.info: Predicate adjective (nominative) - we'll learn adjectives in Concept 004

sentences.translation: The girls are in the forest.

analysis.note: Could also be gen. sg. or dat. sg., but 'sunt' (they are) tells us this is nominative plural

analysis.reason: Ablative of place where (in the forest)

sentences.translation: I give water to the girls.

analysis.note: Could also be ablative plural, but 'to whom' context indicates dative

analysis.info: 1st person singular verb (I give) - you'll learn this verb type in Concept 002

examples.title: Example 4: Common Mistakes and How to Fix Them

mistakes.why_wrong: The ending -ae can be genitive singular, dative singular, OR nominative plural
mistakes.correct_approach: Look at context and other words in the sentence

example.wrong_translation: The life of the girls is good. (X)
example.correct_translation: The life of the girl is good. / The girl's life is good. (✓)
example.explanation: Here puellae is genitive singular (of the girl), not nominative plural (girls). We know because 'vita' is singular and 'est' (is) is singular.

mistakes.error: Relying on word order instead of case endings
mistakes.incorrect_thinking: First word must be the subject
mistakes.why_wrong: Latin word order is flexible - endings show function, not position
mistakes.correct_approach: Identify the case by its ending, not its position

example.explanation: Even though 'viam' comes first, its accusative ending (-am) tells us it's the object, not the subject. 'Puella' (nominative) is the subject.

mistakes.incorrect_thinking: Both are -ae, so they're the same
mistakes.why_wrong: Ablative singular is -ā (long a), dative singular is -ae
mistakes.correct_approach: Notice the macron (ā vs. ae) when present; use context when macrons absent

example.translation_1: I give water to the girl.
example.explanation: In sentence 1, 'to the girl' indicates dative. In sentence 2, 'with the girl' indicates ablative. The macron (puellā) would distinguish them in marked texts.

mistakes.incorrect_thinking: Need to say 'ego sum' for 'I am'
mistakes.why_wrong: Latin verb endings already indicate person
mistakes.correct_approach: Use pronouns only for emphasis or clarity

example.explanation: The ending '-m' in 'sum' already tells us it's 'I.' Add 'ego' only if you mean '**I** am here (not you)'

examples.title: Example 5: Practice Identifying Forms
examples.description: Quick identification drills to test your recognition of forms.

drills.question: What case(s) could 'puellae' be?
drills.answer: Genitive singular, dative singular, OR nominative plural
drills.explanation: All three cases have the same form (-ae). You need context to determine which.

drills.question: If you see 'portārum' in a sentence, what case must it be?
drills.explanation: The ending -ārum is unique to genitive plural in first declension. Translation: 'of the gates'

drills.question: What's the difference between 'puellam' and 'puellās'?
drills.answer: puellam = accusative singular (the girl, as object); puellās = accusative plural (the girls, as object)
drills.explanation: Both are accusative (direct objects), but -am is singular, -ās is plural

drills.question: How do you say 'to the girls' in Latin?
drills.explanation: 'To/for' someone indicates dative case. Plural ending is -īs.

drills.question: What person is 'estis'?
drills.explanation: From sum, esse: estis = you (plural) are

examples.title: Example 6: Building Simple Sentences
examples.description: How to construct basic Latin sentences using what you've learned.

constructions.notes: Simplest sentence type. States existence or presence.

constructions.english: The girl is in the road.
constructions.notes: 'in' + ablative = location ('in/on'). Word order flexible: 'In viā puella est' also works.
Most common word order: Subject-Object-Verb (SOV). But 'Viam puella videt' is equally correct.
Wait, this looks wrong! Actually: 'Vitae' is genitive? No - this should be 'Vita puellae est bona' (vita = nom., puellae = gen.)

constructions.pattern: Subject (nom.) + Indirect Object (dat.) + Direct Object (acc.) + Verb
constructions.english: I give water to the girl.
constructions.notes: Dative shows recipient. Notice: no 'I' pronoun needed - 'do' means 'I give'

examples.practice_prompt: Try building your own sentences using: puella, via, aqua, sum, and the verb 'video' (I see)!

examples.title: Example 7: Case Function Summary Chart
examples.description: Quick reference for when to use each case.

case_functions.example: Vita puellae (The girl's life / life of the girl)
Puellae aquam do. (I give water to the girl.)
Cum puellā sum. (I am with the girl.)
